subject: json_utils: Add support for multiple level json read
commitMessage:
json_utils: Add support for multiple level json read

Added support for multiple level direct read. For example, we can now
access `abc/xyz` directly instead of getting `abc` and then abc[`xyz`].

For extra element error, it will only be triggered if the element at the
root level is not a parent of any of the requested elements.

For example,

{
    "abc": {
        "xyz": 12
    }
}

Getting "abc/xyz" will satisfy the condition so it does not throw an
error.

This is accomplished in a reasonable way by moving the previously
variadic templated code to a std::span<variant> that contains all
possible types.  This is a trick learned from the fmt library to reduce
compile sizes, as the majority of the code doesn't get duplicated at
template level, and is instead operating on the fixed variant type.

This commit drops 7316 bytes (about half a percent of total) from the
bmcweb binary size from the reduction in template usage.  Later patches
build on this patchset to simplify call sites even more and reduce the
binary size further, but as is, this is still a win.

Note: now that the UnpackVariant lists all possible unpack types, it was
found that readJson would fail to compile for vector<bool>.  This is a
well known C++ deficiency in the std::vector<bool> type when compared to
all other types, and will need special handling in the future.  The two
types for vector<bool> are left commented out in the typelist.


Tested: Unit tests passing with reasonable coverage.  Functional use in
next commit in this series.

Change-Id: Ifb247c9121c41ad8f1de26eb4bfc3d71484e6bd6
Signed-off-by: Willy Tu <wltu@google.com>
Signed-off-by: Ed Tanous <edtanous@google.com>

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as ea2e6eeca15f4019923466f7c8ccc52c53a5ea94
Do we have any cases in code that actually require pulling out by a single array index?  I'd rather avoid the code until we have a valid use case.

In my opinion:

While checking for keys in map during readJson is a valid case it seems like even if we have case that read only one element from array it should be changed to iterating over array.
i think I agree, but as far as I know, we don't have the case of a fixed size array, so I suspect we can ignore it for the moment and leave it unimplemented.
Same here, never seen any case where fixed size array way in json.
This was making the handlers const correct, which in the one variation of the patchset was needed, but I don't think is needed anymore.

Need more details on what you mean here.

With that said, I've removed this typedef entirely and went back to what it was before.
NVM, I see the failure in clang-tidy.  That whole line is now gone and reverted back to the old one.
how some this is commented out?

I'll answer in the commit message, but it turns out this code never could unpack vector<bool> properly, because of c++ bool funness.  Luckily, we don't actually use it anywhere.  It's left here as a comment to remind someone that while it is valid, at this point, commenting in this line won't compile.

> nit: revert the logic instead?
> 

Done.

> ```
> if (key != item.key() || unpackSpec.complete)
> {
>   continue;
> }
> ```
> 
> ---
> 
> Correct me if I am wrong. Based on my understanding if we have request for `test/a` and `test/b` with
> 
> ```
> {
>   "test": {
>     "a": 0,
>     "b": 1,
>   }
> }
> ```
> 
> When it is doing `test/a` and went into `test/` it will also compete `test/b`, right? So when we get to `test/b` it will already be completed?

Correct.  Ideally we'd enforce that all the keys be alphabetical to avoid the n^2 lookup times, but given the set sizes, N^2 should be relatively small in most cases, and we can optimize to rely on the alphabeticalness of these items at their call site in the future if we choose later, but at this point I think we can push that to a later patch.

this should always be true, right?

Do we have to check explicitly?

Or just check if `p.key` starts with key + "/" instead? Maybe that's too much for this.

> this should always be true, right?
> 

I don't think so.  thisKey is based on p, which is a second loop through the span, and each entry might, or might not have the same prefix as the thing we're searching for.

> Do we have to check explicitly?

I think we do, but I could always be wrong, what do you think the logic should be instead?

> 
> Or just check if `p.key` starts with key + "/" instead? Maybe that's too much for this.

Made the change, and it does seem cleaner, and with that change it does remove this.  Take a look at the latest code and see if it does what you were thinking.

yeah, looks fine.

Although,

I think

```
if (!p.key.starts_with(key))
```

should be 

```
if (!p.key.starts_with(key + '/'))
```

since it will fetch extra elements for

`test0/1` and `test/1` if the key is `test`

This is subtle, which I don't like, so I added a comment that I think you missed.  Look at line 427, where we change the definition of "key" to include the trailing slash.  I think the code works as written.

I tried emplace_back, and while it does compile with gcc, clang refused to construct it regardless of whether I added braces or not.  I'm pretty sure no matter what we have to build a temporary.

Feel free to play around with it, and if there's some combination I didn't try that makes emplace_back compile with both clang and gcc here, I'm happy to do it.  I will fully admit, I don't understand all the rules for emplace_back on a POD struct.
oh interesting. I guess its fine.
do we need to check index out of bound here?

oh yeah, I was working on something like this. Just parse the requested variables and use while parsing the json input and exist once that is done. Seems like this cover everything that I wanted from that idea.
At some point it would be nice if the perVariant structure could do the splitting into some kind of trie structure, but that's a problem for another day I think.
Yes.  Although it should be using std::move here.

Is this ever true?

compare against std::nullopt instead?

As always, happy to discuss, but this patchset has been up for over a month, and to me seems like a great improvement in how much code we write (as can be seen by the subsequent patch which is -90 lines for the same functionality).
